awd_titl_txt: SBP: Developmental mechanisms underlying the emergence of racial bias
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will provide new insights into how racial biases emerge and develop in early childhood. Racism remains a pervasive force with widespread and well-documented harmful consequences. An important step towards redressing these problems is understanding the psychological processes that maintain and reinforce them. Young children begin to develop harmful and problematic beliefs about race in early childhood (often by 3 years of age), and a majority of children and adolescents of color report experiencing racially-based discrimination. Yet, some children develop stronger racial biases than others, suggesting that the persistence of racial bias is not inevitable. This project will reveal how racial biases emerge and develop in children living across the United States and will examine how parent-child conversations might lead children to form harmful beliefs about race (or serve to prevent them). In doing so, this project will address fundamental questions about how racial biases take root in early childhood and will identify ways that parents can prevent this development. By partnering with several community organizations to implement this project and using an innovative, webcam-based lab for remote developmental research, this project will maximize the opportunities for this research to lead to rapid changes in parenting practices with the potential to reduce the emergence of racial bias in early childhood. 

The first part of this project will explore the foundational beliefs that predict the emergence and development of racial bias in children across the United States via a longitudinal study with 300 children and parents who will participate in this research from home using an online lab. This project will examine how children’s emerging beliefs about interracial friendships and racial inequalities predict the future development of racial biases. Specifically, every six months over a three year period, children will complete a series of assessments that gauge their racial biases (e.g., how much they like and want to play with Black and White children), their beliefs about interracial friendships (who their parents would want them to play with, who their friends would want to play with), and whether they believe that racial inequalities are due to essentialist (e.g., inherent/intrinsic differences between racial groups) or structural (e.g., differential access to resources and opportunities) factors. This study will test the hypotheses that children who hold more exclusive beliefs about interracial friendships and more essentialist beliefs about racial inequalities will develop higher levels of racial biases. The second part of this project will explore an important developmental mechanism by which children develop problematic beliefs about interracial friendships and racial inequalities: parent-child conversations. Using our online lab, 105 children and parents will complete a series of role-playing activities designed to spur conversations about racial inequalities; conversations will be coded for subtle linguistic cues that imply that racial and socioeconomic groups reflect inherently different types of people, as well as for essentialist and structural explanations for racial disparities. These features of parent-child conversations will then be used to predict children’s racial biases and foundational beliefs as in Part A. Thus, this project will advance our understanding of how racial biases emerge and develop in early childhood. By identifying the core features of parent-child conversations that can foster or impede these beliefs, this project will also inform future interventions aimed at reducing the development of racial bias. By disseminating the results of this research via our online lab, we will enable easy access to our findings for researchers, parents, educators, and policy makers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project revealed novel insights into the psychological processes and developmental mechanisms underlying the emergence of racial bias by identifying key predictors of variation in bias among children living across the United States. Racial biases take root in early childhood, are pervasive in adolescence and adulthood, and lead to numerous negative health, education, and economic outcomes for members of marginalized racial and ethnic groups. Yet, there is considerable variation in the degree to which children develop these biases—some children develop more racial bias than others. This project enhanced our understanding of how and why racial biases emerge and develop during childhood by examining the developmental mechanisms and psychological processes involved in the formation of racial biases in a 3-year longitudinal study (Part A) and a naturalistic observation of parent-child conversations about race and racism (Part B). By identifying the psychological processes and developmental mechanisms underlying the emergence of racial biases, this project contributed to our basic understanding of how racial biases emerge and develop during childhood and provides novel, actionable, insights for applied and intervention research aimed at preempting the formation of racial biases. Further, through partnerships with three NGO organizations—Embrace Race, Story Starters, and We Stories—this project maximized opportunities for this research to have a direct impact on educators, parents, and children.

Racial and ethnic biases emerge in children living in countries across the world by 3- to 4-years-old (Raabe & Beelmann, 2011). In the United States, anti-Black biases are particularly well documented in young children (Rizzo et al., 2021, 2022; Roberts & Rizzo, 2021). The present studies examined how and why these biases develop by examining beliefs that might predict when and which children will develop racial biases. We found that children who believed that racial inequalities were caused by intrinsic differences between racial groups were especially likely to develop racial biases over time. Importantly, we also found that children’s beliefs about racial inequalities are especially important for children as they navigate contexts involving racial inequality and segregation in their daily lives. For example, White children living in neighborhoods with a greater degree of Black/White racial inequality who endorsed intrinsic beliefs about racial inequalities were especially likely to hold racial biases compared to those who had less experience with racial inequalities (Rizzo et al., 2022) and White children living in more racially homogenous communities were less likely to endorse intrinsic explanations for racial inequalities if they had more diverse social networks (Burke et al., 2023). In the second part of this project, we examined the role that parents play in children’s developing beliefs by recording parents and children talking about topics related to race and racism (e.g., “Why do people have different skin colors?”, “Why do some people have more money than others?”). In this study, we found that the linguistic form that families use when talking about race is particularly important in children’s developing beliefs about race; children in families who used more generic racial labels (e.g., “Black people”, “Asians”)—as opposed to specific racial labels (e.g., “These Black people”, “Kamalah Harris is Indian and Black”)—were more likely to hold anti-Black attitudes. This project addressed its Intellectual Merit aims by identifying key psychological processes and developmental mechanisms implicated in the formation of racial biases during early childhood. Further, this project met its Broader Impact goals by providing training in developmental science, broadly disseminating the findings to communities of interest, and yielding novel insights that can inform applied and intervention research aimed at preempting the emergence of racial biases during childhood.
